"How slow we drive —  but yet the hour will come</br>When friends shall greet me with affection's kiss—</br>When seated at my boyhood's happy home,</br>I shall enjoy that mild contented bliss,</br>Not often met with in a world like this;</br>Then I shall see that brother — youngest born,</br>I used to play with in my sportiveness,</br>And from a mother's silence I shall learn</br>A parent's thanks to God — for a lov'd son's return.

"And there is one, who, with a down-cast eye,</br>Will be the last to welcome me — but yet</br>My memory tells me of a parting sigh,</br>And of a cheek with tears of sorrow wet,</br>And how she bade me never to forget</br>A friend — and blush'd. — And I shall see again</br>The look of kindness, as when last we met</br>And parted? — Tell me then that life is vain:</br>That joy, if met with once, is seldom met again."

—see ye not the falling, fallen mass!</br>Hark!  hear ye not the drowning swimmer's cry?</br>Look on the ruins of the desperate pass;</br>Gaze at the hurried ice that rushes by,</br>Bearing a freight of wo and agony</br>To that last harour, where we all must go.</br>Resistless as the stormy clouds that fly</br>Above our reach, is that dark stream below—</br>Like time, it knows no ebb, till it has ceas'd to flow.</br>
